block.p: Re ''For Top Executives, a Need to Be Aware of the Nearest Exit'' (The Count, Jan. 14), which described a record number of chief-executive departures from United States companies last year:
Why should a chief executive remain in office when he is guaranteed a fabulous retirement package that is not tied to the company's bottom line? Where is the incentive to produce?
Re ''For Top Executives, a Need to Be Aware of the Nearest Exit'' (The Count, Jan. 14), which described a record number of chief-executive departures from United States companies last year:
Why should a chief executive remain in office when he is guaranteed a fabulous retirement package that is not tied to the company's bottom line? Where is the incentive to produce?
I am certain that there are many qualified candidates for C.E.O. jobs who would work for (literally) millions less than stockholders are now paying.
